webTitle: Letters: Our investment will offer broadband on tap

fields.body:
Aditya Chakrabortty (The great broadband scam, G2, 13 August), suggests that public funds intended to improve rural broadband are bankrolling BT's attempt to widen choice in a pay-TV market dominated by Sky. The suggestion is untrue. We would not be allowed to divert the rural broadband subsidies and nor would we want to. In fact BT's shareholders are supplementing them with hundreds of millions of additional investment – building on the £2.5bn BT is already investing in fibre broadband. The company is accepting a payback period in excess of 10 years for all of this investment – a crucial fact that helps to explain why BT is winning through in the competitive tenders for use of rural broadband subsidy.

As for claims of lack of transparency over BT's costs, full account of these is available to central and local government partners who are subsidising improvements in rural broadband. And BT claims the money only after it's been spent, on production of receipts for expenditure. Independent studies show the UK already second in the G8 for broadband speed and ahead of every major EU rival for availability and low prices. Claims that Jersey is the only place in the UK able to access broadband speeds of 1 gigabyte per second are also stunningly wrong. Your writer might wander around the City of London just for starters. When it comes to broadband rollout, Britain has an infrastructure programme that's working – so much so that the Australian opposition wants to junk that country's programme and copy ours. As for BT's so-called monopoly: rivals like Sky and TalkTalk can, and do, use the network we're building, paying the same prices we charge our own retail division.
Michael Prescott
Director of corporate affairs, BT Group

• You imply (Editorial, 13 August) that Thames Water should follow Welsh Water, which "prides itself on low price rises and high levels of investment". I agree. At Thames Water we are investing a record £1bn a year from 2010-15 upgrading our old pipes, sewers and other facilities - more than any company ever has - and our customers' bills are the second-lowest in England and Wales. A key factor in enabling us to carry out sustained high levels of work to improve our infrastructure is retaining our investment-grade credit rating, currently A3 from Moody's – as good as the best in the sector and the same as Welsh Water.
Stuart Siddall
Chief finance officer, Thames Water

webTitle: Barclays' finance chief Chris Lucas  to leave six months early

fields.standfirst: Departure of finance director Chris Lucas due to health issues first announced in February was not expected before next year
fields.body:
Speculation is mounting that Barclays' finance director was preparing to leave the bank six months earlier than planned, leaving the bank without a key boardroom figure during its £6bn cash call.

The departure of Chris Lucas had been expected early next year and was first announced in February when it was said that he had health problems which had a bearing on his decision to retire but had not affected his ability to do his job. His deteriorating health is said to be the reason for the acceleration in his retirement and last month, Lucas was notably absent from the bank's half year results presentation to journalists when it announced the cash call.

The retirement of the 52 year old could now take place as soon as this week, leaving the bank without a vital boardroom director during the crucial fundraising which is not being formally launched until next month.

His replacement was named a month ago as Tushar Morzaria who is moving to London from New York to take up the crucial post in the autumn and had been expecting a long handover period with Lucas who was intending to stay to see the full year results through, in February.

Lucas, who started discussing his retirement with the new chief executive, Antony Jenkins, before Christmas last year, is also one of four current and former directors being investigated by City regulators over disclosures made during its the 2008 fund raisings that prevented the bank taking a taxpayer bailout. Barclays would not comment last night.

Alongside its results for the first half of 2013, the bank also revealed that it had been informed of the findings of the investigation by the Financial Conduct Authority, and was contesting the findings.

At the time Jenkins refused to elaborate on the FCA findings and the bank's formal statement said that it expected "further developments in the near term".

While the new finance director Morzaria is joining in the autumn – by which time the cash call is due to be completed – he is not scheduled to join the board until January which appears to leave Jenkins as the only full-time executive on the bank's board. It is thought possible that Morzaria could join the board earlier.

While investors knew Lucas would be leaving, they would have been expecting the finance director to play a significant role during the cash call which is taking the form of a rights issue.

Under the terms announced last month investors will be offered one share at 185p for every four shares they own and the bank will raise £5.8bn after fees have been paid to the investment banks guaranteeing the share issue.

The cash call is taking place after the Prudential Regulation Authority set a tougher capital test for the bank requiring it to meet a leverage test. Jenkins, promoted 11 months ago in the wake of the Libor rigging scandal, has argued that the rights issue is "about doing the best for our shareholders".

He replaced Bob Diamond who had quit following the £290m fine for rigging Libor, along with the former chairman Marcus Agius and chief operating officer Jerry del Missier.

webTitle: iSoft co-founder Patrick Cryne may face disciplinary action in role as accountant

fields.standfirst: Financial Reporting Council considers reopening investigation into software group's accounting scandal
fields.body:
Patrick Cryne, the multi-millionaire co-founder of scandal-hit NHS software group iSoft, could face disciplinary action over his conduct as an accountant despite being told last month that seven-year-long efforts to bring a criminal prosecution against him had failed.

Cryne, who made £41m from selling shares in iSoft between 2001 and 2005, had been the main target for prosecutors at the Financial Conduct Authority, previously known as the Financial Services Authority.

However, the regulator last month ditched its case against Cryne and three other former iSoft executives after a trial at Southwark crown court in London collapsed amid serious procedural failings in the prosecution case. No longer working in healthcare IT, Cryne – who denies wrongdoing at iSoft – is now best known as co-owner of Championship football club Barnsley FC. With Steve Graham, who was once iSoft chief operations officer and was also acquitted, he co-owns Vale Royal Abbey, a luxury banqueting venue and golf course in Cheshire.

The Financial Reporting Council – the accountancy watchdog with powers to fine and strike off accountants – has told the Guardian it is considering reopening its investigation into the iSoft accounting scandal. The news follows the FCA's decision to abandon any prosecution of Cryne and other former iSoft directors. The FRC can only pursue disciplinary actions against accountants, such as Cryne, who are members of certain accredited professional bodies, including the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales.

A spokesman said: "In view of the outcome of the FCA criminal proceedings we will need to review this case generally, and in particular in respect of [our] investigation of the members who were the subject of the FCA criminal proceedings."

Last week the FRC unsealed details of a past disciplinary action against iSoft's auditor, laying bare a catalogue of accounting failures that had misled investors between 2003 and 2005. The FRC findings against RSM Robson Rhodes – now part of Grant Thornton – and its top audit partner Glyn Williams went beyond the narrow matter of the single Irish healthcare IT contract that was the focus of the FCA's failed criminal prosecution. The accountancy regulator's conclusions also make clear iSoft had been misleading investors about revenues from NHS contracts in 2003 and 2004, including a period when the Guardian had begun to question whether iSoft was misrepresenting its NHS contract revenues.

The recently unsealed FRC report said: "The accounting for iSoft's major contracts was not appropriate in 2003 and 2004 accounts and these accounts therefore did not show a true and fair view of the state of affairs of iSoft.

"Robson Rhodes, and in particular Mr Williams, failed to identify that iSoft's major contracts should have been accounted for in a manner so as to spread more revenues across the term of the contract and less recognised upfront; and failed to qualify their audit opinion … in respect of income recognition."

In 2004, iSoft secured a gagging order against the Guardian preventing publication of an article on the company. ISoft told the Guardian any planned article would be based on a leaked confidential document that contained inaccuracies and did not tell the whole picture. Concerns over iSoft's response to the Guardian led to questions being raised in the House of Commons.

At the time Lord Jones, then director-general of the CBI and a non-executive director of iSoft, accused the paper of "serious and unfounded insinuations of impropriety". Having been a member of iSoft's audit committee, he said he had thoroughly looked into concerns raised and was "satisfied that the company has followed best practice".

Also speaking in 2004, the then chief executive Tim Whiston, said: "There are no questionable accounting practices. The accounts for the company have never been called into question. Indeed … the accounting standards applied have received nothing but positive commendations."

Whiston went on to be among those accused – and acquitted – of criminally misleading investors. Jones, who went on to be ennobled and serve as a UK trade minister, continued to defend the record of Cryne as late as July 2006, when a string of profits warnings prompted concerns about iSoft's aggressive accounting to resurface. Jones, who had left iSoft the year before, told a newspaper Cryne was a "true Yorkshireman". "He had foresight. He was one of the industry's great visionaries." A month later, new auditors Deloitte confirmed it was conducting an inquiry into "accounting irregularities".

Jones ultimately appeared as a prosecution witness in the failed trial. He told the Guardian he did not wish to comment on the FRC's findings of multiple failures in iSoft's accounts.

Cryne had not himself been put in the dock by the FCA because of ill health, but had been expected to face trial separately at a later date. Last month's aborted trial was the second time the iSoft defendants had faced a jury. An initial trial had failed to produce a verdict last year, triggering a retrial.

The FCA quickly confirmed it would not seek a third trial. Tracey McDermott, FCA director of enforcement and financial crime, described it as a "disappointing outcome", adding "we will look to see what lessons can be learned for the future".

Manchester-based iSoft floated in 2000, six years after Cryne and Graham had helped spin the healthcare IT business out of KPMG. Changing its name from KPMG Health Systems, the company became a FTSE 250 firm and reached a share value of more than £1bn before a series of profits warnings and the discovery of accounting irregularities in 2006.

At trial, the FSA prosecution claimed there had been a forgery plot to create the illusion of a big contract win in Ireland. This allegedly constituted about half of iSoft's half-year revenues in October 2003. Although terms had been agreed on the Irish contract, signing could not be carried out in time for iSoft's financial reporting deadline in autumn 2003 — in part because the £38.5m spending commitment required Irish ministerial sign-off.

One email in October 2003 from Graham to an iSoft colleague in Ireland said: "What the **** is going on with Pat McLoughlin [a Irish civil servant]?" A later Graham email that day said: "So what next? Is this not important enough for him to clear two hours between 15 and 24 October? If he doesn't we are fucked." A box was later found by FSA investigators containing what was described by prosecuting counsel in court as a "forgery kit". Where this file had been located became an important issue at the trial.

Cryne has consistently denied wrongdoing, saying he is "absolutely satisfied that in due course my position will be completely vindicated". His lawyer told the Guardian: "I draw your attention to the fact that Mr Cryne did not play any part in either of the trials. Therefore any reference to matters which may have been admitted by the defendants are not matters which can be imputed to Mr Cryne. He made no such admission."

The company's purported stellar performance in 2003 came at a critical time for the business. Shortly afterwards iSoft was selected as a major sub-contractor within Labour government's £12.7bn 10-year NHS IT overhaul – the largest non-military computer upgrade in the world.

About the same time, a soaring share price also helped the business take over rival group Torex, which was bought with iSoft shares.

Collapsed trial

The case against four former iSoft directors collapsed over a missing file. The Financial Conduct Authority decided not to pursue a third trial against Stephen Graham, 49, Timothy Whiston, 45, and John Whelan, 46, after a jury was dismissed last month over a procedural problem.

Patrick Cryne, 62, who had not been put on trial because of ill health, was also told that he would not be facing prosecution.

It was only the second criminal case of conspiracy to mislead the markets and £5m of taxpayers' money was spent on the case. The state must now pick up the defendants' legal costs.

The case hit the buffers when the FCA's barrister disclosed a note from 2009 that the defence had not seen. The judge dismissed the jury and ended the trial because the defence would have needed time to study the document.

The first trial collapsed in 2012 after the jury failed to reach a verdict. Commenting after the verdict, iSoft's former chief operating officer, Stephen Graham, said his life had been on hold since the investigation began in 2006.

"In that time I have had to stand by and watch the company I dedicated 20 years of my life to creating and building, systematically managed out of existence," Graham said.

webTitle: Inflation profile: Mal Curry, 50 - Royal Mail sorting office worker

fields.standfirst: Small annual wage rises fail to keep pace with ballooning bills
fields.body:
In some ways, Mal Curry is one of the lucky ones in these straitened times. A 50-year-old "lifer" working at a Royal Mail sorting office in Manchester for 31 years, he has been granted pay rises through most of the recession and now earns around £9 an hour.

But the small annual increases have failed to keep up with galloping inflation which he says has doubled his utility bills over the last five years. "I've got a meter and every week I used to put £5 on the electric and £5 on the gas. Now both are a tenner," he said outside the Oldham Road depot on Tuesday.

Curry, who lives alone in Worsley in Salford, has made small changes to stay afloat. His nightly bath has been replaced with a shower, and whereas he used to go to the pub every Friday, now he buys four cans from the off licence instead. "Four for £5.50," he said, "and that's a pound more than it was not so long ago."

Now, he said, "you go to work for a social life. I only go out once a month now, and I'm home after four pints."

He brings his own teabags to work these days, balking at the price increases in the Royal Mail canteen – a cup of tea now costs 58p, up from 25p a go, he claimed. He's more likely to be seen in Aldi than Tesco and he puts cheaper things in his trolley, shunning expensive brands. "I keep away from the Warburtons bread," he said, by way of example.

Curry used to treat himself to an annual holiday in America – Cuba, Mexico, Costa Rica – but for the first time in years, has not gone away at all this summer. "This year I couldn't afford it," he said.

This year, Royal Mail workers have yet to receive a pay rise after their union rejected an 8.6% pay rise as a "misleading and unacceptable" sweetener from a company desperate to win over staff ahead of plans to privatise the 497-year-old postal service.

The Communication Workers Union (CWU), which represents more than 100,000 Royal Mail staff, said the 8.6% increase in basic pay over three years was "only there as a sweetener to swallow some very bitter pills" including "damaging" changes to their pensions and working conditions.

Curry said he objected to below-inflation rises when Royal Mail executives were getting big increases and bumper bonuses. Earlier this month, the group's annual report showed that chief executive Moya Greene received a 33% pay rise last year taking her income to almost £1.5m.

The CWU said Greene's pay was "imitating private sector excess" at a time when workers faced painful cuts in pensions and hours. The union was particularly incensed by a £400,000 bonus paid to Greene alongside a £250,000 payment for her relocating from Canada.

webTitle: Eurozone set to exit 18-month double-dip recession

fields.standfirst: Official figures from Brussels are expected to show a return to modest growth in the three months to June
fields.body:
The 18-month double-dip recession in the crisis-stricken eurozone is expected to end on Wednesday with the release of official figures in Brussels showing the return of modest growth in the three months to June.

News on Tuesday of a pickup factory production across the 17-nation single currency area during the second quarter left financial markets convinced that a downturn stretching back to the end of 2011 is now over.

Analysts said the 1.2% jump in industrial production coupled with a stronger performance by the construction sector would be enough to produce growth of 0.2% or 0.3% during the spring and early summer. That would reverse a fall of 0.2% in the first three months of 2013.

The last piece of data to be released before Wednesday's growth figures showed that the output of the combined manufacturing and energy sectors expanded for the fourth time in five months, helped by a strong performance from the eurozone's biggest economy, Germany.

But with the European commission predicting that 2013 as a whole will see the single currency area contract for a second successive year, economists warned that the formal end of recession was unlikely to herald a period of strong growth. webTitle: Mark Carney needs to watch economic warning signs while the going is good | Larry Elliott

fields.bodyText: Mark Carney has had the dream start as governor of the Bank of England. His predecessor, Mervyn King, had his work cut out in a crisis-ridden second five-year term, grappling with a financial meltdown, a deep slump and a stuttering recovery. Carney's six weeks in Threadneedle Street have seen unemployment come down, growth pick up and – as the latest official figures showed yesterday – price pressures abate. The new captain has been piped aboard the ship just as the storm has blown over. The July fall in inflation was small but significant. There was speculation a couple of months ago that one of Carney's first tasks as governor would be to write to George Osborne explaining why inflation was more than a percentage point above the government's 2% target. That proved overly-pessimistic and after rising to 2.9% in June, inflation edged down to 2.8% in July. Further falls can be expected over the months to come as the quite chunky monthly price rises in the late summer and autumn of 2012 are replaced by smaller increases this year. Last year, prices rose by 0.5% in August, 0.4% in September and 0.5% in October, and unless there is an unexpected spike in the cost of food and fuel similar increases look improbable in 2013. Martin Beck, analyst at Capital Economics said the upshot is that inflation will be quite close to 2% by the end of the year, considerably lower than the Bank's own forecast, which shows it still hovering close to 3%. This matters both for the Bank and the wider economy. Firstly, it will suggest that the long period of above-target inflation is drawing to an end. Since 2007, the only time the annual increase in the cost of living has been running below 2% was during the winter of 2008-09 when the economy was imploding. The rest of the time, it has been above target, twice peaking at more than 5%. There is only so long a central bank can fail to meet a legally constituted inflation target without losing credibility. The second reason falling inflation matters is that it removes one of the obstacles to keeping interest rates low. Carney said last week that the Bank's monetary policy committee intended to keep the cost of borrowing at its record low of 0.5% but there were certain circumstances in which a re-think might be necessary. One of those circumstances would be a forecast that inflation in 18-24 months time would be higher than 2.5%. The Bank has never forecast inflation of higher than 2.5%, even when it was running at more than 5%, so the chances of it doing so when inflation is coming down seem remote to say the least. Finally, falling inflation helps ease the squeeze on real incomes, increasing the chances that the recovery seen in recent months will persist. This effect should not be exaggerated since even after July's fall to 2.8%, prices are still rising faster than earnings, which are going up by 1% a year. Living standards will continue to be eroded during 2013 and early 2014, but by this time next year they could start to rise as inflation falls and a growing economy leads to higher pay settlements. Further out, the risk is that inflationary pressure starts to increase again. The fall in sterling since the start of the financial crisis has made imports dearer. The Bank has kept interest rates ultra low for more than five years and created £375bn of electronic money through quantitative easing; the Treasury is handing out subsidies to home buyers: all the ingredients are there for a housing bubble that has spill over effects into the rest of the economy. Carney and his colleagues would be well advised to keep a close eye on what is happening to real estate, since one of the lessons of the financial crisis is that the economy can come off the rails even when the official measure of the cost of living is well behaved. Looking at official data over coming months it may be tempting to see inflation as yesterday's problem but, Britain being Britain, it is likely to be tomorrow's problem as well.

webTitle: Is the banking system too big? | Jill Treanor

fields.bodyText: How big is too big for a banking system? It is a question that has been posed many times since the 2008 crisis when the phrase "too big to fail" entered the lexicon as taxpayers were forced to bail out their banks or face financial meltdown. Eurozone banks, despite shrinking their balance sheets by €2.9tn (£2.5tn) since May 2012, are still more than three times the size of the 17 economies using the single currency. Alberto Gallo, head of European macro credit research at Royal Bank of Scotland, reckons this is still too large. In a recent research note, he argues that despite shrinking by 8% eurozone banks are only halfway to reaching sustainable levels and need to "deleverage" by a further €3.2tn. Some €661bn of this will come from the 11 largest banks but the bulk of it – €2.6tn – will come from the smaller institutions, which will find it harder to "deleverage" as quickly as the bigger banks. This deleveraging can take place in two main ways. Either banks raise capital (by tapping shareholders or holding on to their profits, say) or they can reduce their assets by pulling out of business lines and cutting back on lending. In practice they do a combination of the two and Gallo estimates that the 11 major banks will need to raise €47bn of capital. If the UK's banks are added then the total amount of extra capital needed is €60bn – and that is on top of the €661bn reduction of assets the banks need to do in the next three to five years. Gallo's calculations are based on 70% of the deleveraging coming from raising capital and 30% by reducing assets. But for the smaller banks he estimates that only 30% can be achieved by raising capital. This begs the question of how the banks finance a recovery in the eurozone while they are drastically shrinking their balance sheets. Gallo points out that policymakers in Europe have already devised a scheme intended to help bolster lending to small and medium-sized businesses by up to €100bn in the next six years. But deleveraging is necessary if banks are to become smaller relative to the size of economies and to meet tougher rules being imposed on banks. Gallo reckons a better sized – and safer – banking system would be two to three times bigger than GDP. Banks in Canada, Australia and Japan are around twice the size of their domestic economies, he points out, while in the US banks are smaller than the size of the economy, partly due to the fact that big companies go straight to the bond markets to raise money to a greater extent than they do in other countries. For the UK Gallo's charts show that the banks are five times the size of the economy. He argues that this includes big international players and stripping out half of HSBC, 90% of Standard Chartered and 70% of Barclays, the UK banking system becomes about 3.5 times the size of the economy. This makes Gallo less worried about the UK banking system than that of the eurozone. Still, the numbers seem too big.

webTitle: New Look scores online sales surge

fields.standfirst: Internet orders up 79% in second quarter as budget fashion retailer consolidates return to profit
fields.body:
An online makeover appears to be paying off for New Look as the budget fashion retailer reported a dramatic surge in internet sales.

Online sales soared 79% in the three months to June, as New Look's net-savvy customers increasingly chose to log on for their dresses and tops. Online now accounts for 10% of all New Look sales, which were £1.5bn in the last financial year.

Total sales were up 1% compared with the previous year, raising expectations that store revamps are helping the company turn the corner after a period of declining sales.

"We are very encouraged by New Look's robust trading performance in the period, in spite of the coldest spring for 50 years," said the company's chief executive, Anders Kristiansen. "We are confident that the improvement to our ranges, the refurbishment of our stores and our growing online strength will underpin further progress."

The company, which reported in June that it had returned to profit after a £55m loss the previous year, said it had made a strong start to trading from July.

As well as refitting more than a quarter of its 590 UK stores, New Look has overhauled its website and developed apps for mobile phones and tablets. Efforts to generate social media buzz have helped it notch up more than 2m likes on Facebook and 121,000 Twitter followers.

Anusha Couttigane, fashion consultant at Conlumino retail analysts, said New Look had made significant improvements to its media approach last year, including the expansion of its "click and collect" network, where customers pick up internet orders from high street stores. But she warned that it would have to keep innovating to stay ahead in this "fickle" market.

The dramatic surge in online sales illustrates how the internet is becoming a bigger priority for budget retailers. In June New Look's rival Primark, which has long shunned the internet, announced it would start selling some of its womenswear through Asos.

"Value players haven't been as focused on online retailing as [they have on] being bricks and mortar retailers," said Couttigane. "Now there is room for growth, even at a value level, because a lot of budget consumers are online too."

webTitle: Justice Department challenges $11bn American Airlines-US Airways merger

fields.bodyText: The US Justice Department on Tuesday moved to block the $11bn merger of American Airlines and US Airways, arguing the deal could reduce competition in local markets and result in higher airfares. The proposed deal would create the world's largest airline and would leave four airlines in control of 80% of the US's commercial air travel market. The Justice Department said a merger would "substantially lessen competition for commercial air travel". AMR, AA's parent company, and US Airways announced their merger in February, and had hoped to complete the deal within months. The merger would be the seventh since 2005 in the rapidly consolidating industry. "By challenging this merger, the Department of Justice is saying that the American people deserve better," said attorney general Eric Holder. "This transaction would result in consumers paying the price – in higher airfares, higher fees and fewer choices." "If this merger goes forward, even a small increase in the price of airline tickets, checked bags or flight change fees would result in hundreds of millions of dollars of harm to American consumers," said Bill Baer, assistant attorney general in charge of the Department of Justice's antitrust division. "Both airlines have stated they can succeed on a standalone basis and consumers deserve the benefit of that continuing competitive dynamic." The lawsuit was filed on behalf of the attorneys general of Arizona, Florida, Tennessee, Texas, Pennsylvania and the District of Columbia. The DOJ singled out Washington, DC, as an example of its concerns about the merger. The merged airline would control 69% of takeoff and landing slots at Washington Reagan national airport and would have a monopoly on 63% of the nonstop routes served out of Reagan. "As a result, Washington area passengers would likely see higher prices and fewer choices if the merger is allowed," the department said in its complaint. In a joint statement released Tuesday afternoon, the airlines vowed to mount a "vigorous and strong defense" to the Justice Department: We believe that the DOJ is wrong in its assessment of our merger. Integrating the complementary networks of American and US Airways to benefit passengers is the motivation for bringing these airlines together. Blocking this procompetitive merger will deny customers access to a broader airline network that gives them more choices," they said. The justice department has not challenged an airline merger since 2000's proposed United-US Airways merger. Since then United and Continental have merged, as have Delta and Northwest. When the deal was announced non-profit group American Antitrust Institute (AAI) called for an investigation, arguing it would substantially reduce competition on a number of routes and deprive smaller communities of air service. According to an AAI study published with the Business Travel Coalition ticket prices rose 20% on some key Delta routes and 30% on several United-Continental routes after their mergers. Bert Foer, AAI president, said he was "surprised and delighted" by the Justice Department's move. "There are some pretty good arguments here that the mergers have gone far enough," he said. Foer said he believed the chances of the merger going through without "major changes" was slim. "The Justice Department is saying there is a national issue here. There are so few players. It's not about a few overlapping routes or minor compromises," he said. The action is the second high profile anti-trust move from the Justice Department this year. The agency moved to block brewing giant Anheuser Busch Inbev's $20.1 bn acquisition of Mexico's Grupo Modelo earlier this year. That deal was modified to win approval.

webTitle: Bill Ackman resigns from JC Penney board after years-long squabble

fields.bodyText: Hedge fund billionaire William Ackman has quit the board of troubled department store group JC Penney, ending three years of acrimony. The company announced his departure Tuesday less than a week after Ackman had demanded the resignation of its chairman and CEO. The retailer has appointed Ronald Tysoe, former vice-chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc, now Macy's Inc, to its board and is seeking another director. "At this time, I believe that the addition of two new directors and my stepping down from the board is the most constructive way forward for JC Penney and all other parties involved," Ackman said in a statement released by the company. Ackman's Pershing Square Capital is the retailer's largest shareholder and has been a persistent critic of the company's management. Pershing started buying shares three years ago at prices well above the $12.70 they now trade for, and has lost as much as $600m on its investment. Last week Ackman called for chairman Thomas Engibous and interim chief executive Myron Ullman to step down. Announcing Ackman's departure the company said its board had given its "overwhelming support" to the executives. Ullman, 64, is a former Penney chief executive who was rehired following the departure of Ron Johnson, former head of Apple's stores, whose disastrous tenure led to a dramatic drop in sales at the stores group. fields.headline: Bill Ackman resigns from JC Penney board after years-long squabble
fields.body:
Hedge fund billionaire William Ackman has quit the board of troubled department store group JC Penney, ending three years of acrimony.

The company announced his departure Tuesday less than a week after Ackman had demanded the resignation of its chairman and CEO.

The retailer has appointed Ronald Tysoe, former vice-chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc, now Macy's Inc, to its board and is seeking another director.

"At this time, I believe that the addition of two new directors and my stepping down from the board is the most constructive way forward for JC Penney and all other parties involved," Ackman said in a statement released by the company.

Ackman's Pershing Square Capital is the retailer's largest shareholder and has been a persistent critic of the company's management. Pershing started buying shares three years ago at prices well above the $12.70 they now trade for, and has lost as much as $600m on its investment.

Last week Ackman called for chairman Thomas Engibous and interim chief executive Myron Ullman to step down. Announcing Ackman's departure the company said its board had given its "overwhelming support" to the executives.

Ullman, 64, is a former Penney chief executive who was rehired following the departure of Ron Johnson, former head of Apple's stores, whose disastrous tenure led to a dramatic drop in sales at the stores group.

Sales at JC Penney fell 25% in 2012 and the company reported a $1bn loss as Johnson got rid of the discounting for which the company is famous. Ullman was appointed on a temporary basis after Johnson's departure and the search for his successor continues.

Ackman's resignation will give Pershing Square more flexibility should it decide to begin selling its stake in the company. The company's shares initially rose in reaction to the news but lost the gains by mid-morning.

5.29pm BST

Optimism lifts stocks

This morning's report of growth in eurozone industrial production, improving sentiment in Germany according the ZEW survey, a pick-up in US retail sales and a survey suggesting accelerating UK house price growth have all combined to boost optimism in stock markets around Europe.

A quick summary of main indices before we close the blog for the day:

FTSE 100: +0.6% at 6612

CAC 40: +0.5% at 4093

DAX 30: +0.7% at 8416

IBEX: +0.5% at 8759

DOW JONES: +0.03% at 15,425

S&P 500: -0.1% at 1,689

We will be back tomorrow with coverage of events from around the eurozone, the financial markets and the global economy - as reported earlier, it is a busy day on the data front with eurozone GDP figures at 10am expected to show an exit from recession.

4.05pm BST

Celebrity status

In the UK, the data schedule is busy too tomorrow. Minutes from the latest Bank of England meeting and unemployment data from the Office of National Statistics are both out at 9.30am. France kicks things off with second quarter GDP numbers at 6.30am UK time. The consensus forecast in the Reuters poll of economists is for quarterly growth of 0.2% after a drop of 0.2% in the first quarter. French July inflation figures are at 7.45am.

2.59pm BST

European markets are still slightly higher

FTSE 100: +0.2% at 6585

CAC 40: +0.3% at 4083

DAX 30: +0.6% at 8410

IBEX: +0.1% at 8728

2.38pm BST

US markets open higher

US markets have opened up slightly:

DOW JONES: +0.2% at 15,451

S&P 500: +0.1% at 1,691

Meanwhile the dollar has strengthened on the back of the US retail sales figures, with the underlying picture better than the headline monthly rise of 0.2% suggested.

Here is an extract from the Reuters story:

The dollar climbed to a one-week high against both the euro and the yen on Tuesday after a key gauge of US consumer spending rose at its fastest pace in seven months, strengthening the case for the US Federal Reserve to wind down stimulus.

Retail sales outside of cars, gasoline and building materials rose 0.5% last month, the Commerce Department said on Tuesday. July's gain was the biggest since December, and suggests the economy could be regaining steam after tax hikes and federal budget cuts dragged on growth in the first half of the year.

Updated at 2.47pm BST

2.30pm BST

A quick round-up of the main news so far

  • UK inflation fell to 2.8% in July from 2.9% in June, in line with economists' expectations.
  • US retail sales rose 0.2% in July compared with a month earlier. June's rise was revised up to 0.6% from 0.4%.
  • Eurozone industrial production increased by 0.7% in June, reinforcing expectations that data on Wednesday will confirm an escape from recession for the troubled region in the second quarter.
  • UK house prices are rising at the fastest rate since the 2006 peak according to the RICS.
  • The Nikkei rebounded 2.6% overnight following reports that Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is considering a corporation tax cut.

Updated at 2.33pm BST

2.12pm BST

Christopher Vecchio, currency analyst at dailyfx.com, says the reaction to the US retail sales data suggests investors are expecting the Federal Reserve to start tapering quantitative easing in Q3.

Updated at 2.12pm BST

1.30pm BST

BREAKING: US retail sales rise 0.2%

US retail sales rose 0.2% in July compared with the previous month. That was just below expectations of 0.3%, and lower than June's 0.6% increase (the June rise was revised up from 0.4%).

The biggest increase was sales of sports goods, which were up 1% on the month according to the US Commerce Department data.

Excluding cars, retail sales were 0.5% higher compared with June.

James Knightley of ING says the data continue a positive trend for the US economy but fiscal concerns linger:

This is the fourth consecutive monthly rise and suggests that US consumers are overcoming the headwind from fiscal tightening earlier in the year.

We anticipate further gains in coming months given that consumer confidence is being supported by a strengthening labour market and wealth gains from rising property and stock markets. However, the big unknown is the fallout from any intransigence in Washington over the debt ceiling/fiscal policy. If a deal isn’t done quickly the prospect of government shutdowns and public sector layoffs cold quickly prompt a reversal in sentiment and spending.

Updated at 2.54pm BST

12.48pm BST

US small business confidence rises

Sentiment among small business owners in the US improved in July according to the National Federation of Independent Business.

However a rise in the optimism index to 94.1 from 93.5 was below economists' expectations.

NFIB chief economist Bill Dunkelberg was not in celebratory mood:

In an attempt to 'make lemonade' from the lousy bushel of lemons the administration has handed the small-business community, owners gave the July optimism Index the great distinction of being the fourth highest reading since December 2007— when the economy slipped into official recession.

Unfortunately, nothing is being done to allay the most pressing concerns identified by job creators—dealing with rising health insurance costs, regulations, tax complexity, energy costs and general economic uncertainty. The President wants a deal on 'corporate taxes', but most small businesses are not incorporated. Energy policy is more confused than ever and the volume of new regulations is mounting. Should I even mention the mounting problems with Obamacare? We are in the 'tankeroo,' not sinking, but trying to stay afloat.

Updated at 12.52pm BST

11.54am BST

UK rail fares to increase by an average of 4.1% next year

There are some very unhappy rail passengers today as the UK inflation data confirm that fares in England will rise by an average of 4.1% in January.

That means the price of many commuters' annual season tickets will rise by around £200.

Prices are calculated at July's Retail Prices Index - which came in at 3.1% - plus 1 percentage point.

Read the full story from our transport correspondent Gwyn Topham here.

Updated at 12.59pm BST

11.33am BST

The authors of M&G's Investments' Bond Vigilantes blog are feeling celebratory at the news that Monster Munch is returning to its roots by reverting to the original packet design, size, texture, and flavour.

The bloggers had previously bemoaned a shrinking packet size, and welcome a rare victory for consumers as the makers of the tasty corn snack offer customers better value for money.

James Tomlins of the blog tells us that corn prices are partly to thank:

Since October 2011 the corn future has fallen by around 28.5% in price to $4.64 per bushel, a rare case of deflation in recent times. In sterling terms, the fall is around 25.5%. Updated at 11.33am BST

10.49am BST

Eurozone industrial output rises 0.7% in June

Away from the UK, eurozone industrial output rose 0.7% in June, just shy of the 0.8% forecast by economists but a big improvement on May's 0.2% fall nevertheless.

The rise in June was driven by a 4.9% increase in the production of durable consumer goods. Energy production fell by 1.6% in the eurozone in June according to the EU's statistics office Eurostat.

Biggest jumps in industrial output in June:

Ireland: +8.7%

Germany: +2.5%

Greece: +2.5%

Biggest falls:

Finland: -5.9%

Netherlands: -4.1%

Portugal: -2.8%

June’s eurozone industrial production data and August’s German ZEW survey provide further signs that the eurozone has emerged from recession.

Given this, and the fact that the industrial surveys still only point to small rises in production at best, the pace of expansion may soon ease.

Read our fulll story on UK inflation here.

Politicians have given their reaction to the inflation data.

Today’s figures confirm that prices continue to rise faster than wages as the Tory-led government's cost of living crisis continues. And the government is making things worse not better for families. Alongside declining real wages, tax rises and cuts to tax credits are hitting those on middle and low incomes while millionaires have been given a huge tax cut.

Updated at 10.44am BST

10.30am BST

Reaction to UK inflation fall

Here is some reaction to this morning's data showing annual inflation fell to 2.8% in July from 2.9% in June.

This slightly eases the squeeze on consumers’ purchasing power, although it currently remains appreciable given that inflation is still running nearly three times above underlying annual average earnings growth of 1.0% in the three months to May.

Looking ahead, consumer price inflation may yet touch 3.0% in the near term given difficult near-term base effects and recently firmer oil prices.

The recent rise in petrol prices was only partly captured by today’s release – the bulk of that impact will come next month. It won’t push inflation higher, it will just prevent the slowdown that we would otherwise have had.

Updated at 10.34am BST

10.10am BST

The German ZEW, a monthly measure of sentiment among investors and analysts, has risen more than expected.

The economic sentiment index increased to 42 in August from 36.3 in July, reaching its highest level since March and beating expectations of a more modest rise to 40.

The current conditions index rose to 18.3 from 10.6, against expectations of a more modest rise to 12.

The German think-tank which publishes the monthly survey said:

First signs of an end to the recession in important eurozone countries may have contributed to the indicator’s rise.

This is also reflected by the strong increase of economic expectations for the eurozone. Furthermore, the economic optimism is supported by the robust domestic demand in Germany.

Official figures published on Wednesday are expected to show the eurozone finally emerged from recession in the second quarter, with 0.2% growth.

Updated at 10.19am BST

9.30am BST

BREAKING: UK inflation falls to 2.8%

The annual rate of inflation fell to 2.8% in July, from 2.9% in June according to the Office for National Statistics's Consumer Prices Index. That was exactly in line with economists' expectations.

The Retail Prices Index fell to 3.1% from 3.3%, again in line with forecasts.

The largest drivers of the fall were air fares, plus price movements in the recreation and culture, and clothing and footwear sectors. A rise in petrol and diesel prices partially offset the fall, the ONS said.

Despite the fall, CPI inflation remains above the Bank of England's 2% target.

Meanwhile annual UK factory gate inflation rose to 2.1% in July from 2% in June. On a monthly basis prices were up 0.2% compared with 0.1% in June.

Updated at 2.05pm BST

9.05am BST

RICS: UK house prices rising at fastest rate since 2006 peak

In case you missed it, there was a bullish report on the UK housing market from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors overnight.

It will no doubt give critics of the government's Help to Buy scheme further ammunition. Business secretary Vince Cable and the former Bank of England governor Lord King are among those to have voiced concerns over a potential housing bubble.

Citigroup economist Michael Saunders said the RICS report is consistent with annual house price inflation reaching 10%-plus in the next couple of quarters.

Here is an extract from the Guardian's story on the RICS survey from economics reporter Katie Allen:

George Osborne's schemes to kickstart house sales have fuelled a surge in interest from homebuyers and the fastest rise in prices since their peak seven years ago, according to a wide-ranging survey of estate agents.

In the latest indication that a recovery in the property market is under way, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said that Help to Buy and other initiatives have prompted the sector to "turn a corner" after its post-recession slump. Its monthly report says prices are up for a fourth consecutive month as buyers return to the market in their biggest numbers for four years.

Read the full story here.

Updated at 9.13am BST

8.31am BST

European markets open higher

All the major European indices are up in early trading.

FTSE 100: +0.6% at 6611

CAC 40: +0.2% at 4079

DAX 30: +0.6% at 8412

IBEX: +0.3% at 8748

Updated at 8.43am BST

8.18am BST

The agenda today - UK inflation, German ZEW, US retail sales

A quick look at what's coming up later today:

UK inflation - 9.30am
UK factory gate inflation - 9.30am
Eurozone industrial production - 10am
German ZEW survey - 10am
US NFIB small business survey - 12.30pm
US retail sales - 1.30pm

Read our preview of UK inflation data for July here. The Office for National Statistics data expected to show a slight easing in price pressures, with the annual rate falling to 2.8% from 2.9% in June. 

Next up, Germany's ZEW survey is expected to show an improvement in economic sentiment and current conditions according to analysts and investors after an unexpected deterioration last month.

Eurozone industrial production data for June are expected to show monthly growth of 0.8% after a decline of 0.3% the month before.

Finally, in the US, retail sales data for July are expected to show a 0.3% rise after June's 0.4% increase.

Updated at 9.10am BST

7.46am BST

German inflation is 1.9% in July

Germany's annual rate of inflation on the consumer prices index was 1.9% in July, up from 1.8% in June and in line with expectations. It was the highest rate since December 2012.

A breakdown of the data from the statistics agency showed annual food inflation is now running at 5.1% in Germany, the highest level in almost five years.

The price of "edible oils and fats", including butter, was 30.8% higher in July than a year earlier.

Updated at 8.11am BST

7.46am BST

Nikkei rebounds 2.6%

Good morning all. Welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the eurozone, the financial markets and the global economy.

Japan's Nikkei rebounded strongly after those disappointing GDP numbers drove the index lower on Monday. It closed up 2.6% on Tuesday at 13,867.00.

The reason for renewed optimism? Another dose of Abenomics. Rumours were rife that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is considering a corporate tax cut to offset the potential drag of a planned sales tax hike.

Reports overnight suggested Abe has called for a study on lowering the rate, which at 38% is one of the highest in the industrial world. The hope would no doubt be that cutting the rate would lead to increased capital expenditure, an area which has been dragging growth in the country down.

webTitle: E.ON reports 15% rise in profits from UK customers

fields.standfirst: German energy firm, which raised domestic prices by 8.7% this year, also benefited from March freeze and late summer
fields.body:
Energy company E.ON has reported a 15% surge in profits from its UK customers, after a March deep-freeze and late arrival of summer sent demand soaring.

The German-owned company, which supplies power to 4.8m households and 500,000 businesses, reported profits of £273m in the first six months of the year, up from £238m the year before. The earnings boost comes after the company raised energy bills by 8.7%, taking the average bill to £1,261 a year.

Britain's six biggest energy companies, including E.ON, were recently criticised by MPs for a lack of transparency over their prices. Tony Cocker, E.ON's UK chief executive, insisted the company had delivered a "fair" profit. "The colder start to the year meant more energy has been used, so sales are up. The costs we control have come down at a time when those we don't control are continuing to rise – meaning that ultimately whilst our profit has increased slightly our overall supply profit margin is very much in line with last year."

The company also benefited from the late start to summer with sales rising by 10%, thanks particularly to the low temperatures in March. Earnings from its power generation business fell by more than half to £159m, mainly as a result of the closure of the Kingsnorth coal-fired power station in Kent. The company reports profits by calculating earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda).

E.ON UK said gas-fired power stations were generating "very low profit margins", a trend that pushed down pre-tax earnings across the group by 15% to €5.7bn (£4.9bn) for the first half of this year.

Group chief executive Johannes Teyssen warned investors that "no recovery is in sight", as low wholesale prices and falling demand for gas-generated power weigh on the business.

"Our traditional generation business is suffering from low capacity utilisation and excessively low wholesale prices," he wrote in a letter to shareholders. "These adverse factors will continue, and according to our analysis, may actually get worse."

E.ON announced last month that it would mothball an unprofitable gas-fired power plant in Malženice, Slovakia, barely two years after the €400m plant went into service.

"These kinds of decisions are never easy," Teyssen wrote. "Unless the business environment of the energy industry in our core European markets changes tangibly, other plant closures will be unavoidable."

The growing supply of renewable energy, which has priority access to the grid, has meant traditional fossil-fuel plants are not always operating at their maximum potential. E.ON said that its profitable renewable business continued to grow, but not fast enough to offset the decline in earnings from gas. Renewable energy sales rose 3% to €1.3bn in the first half of the year, driven by expansion in its wind and solar energy business.

E.ON is a co-owner of the world's largest wind farm, the London Array, which is located just off the Kent and Suffolk coast and able to meet the annual electricity needs of 750,000 homes, following its official launch in July. Further renewable energy projects are in the pipeline. In April E.ON began laying the sandbag foundations for the Amrumbank wind farm in the North Sea. It has also recently put its first US solar farms into service.

webTitle: Private equity firm CVC pays £750m for Domestic & General

fields.standfirst: CVC buys company which sells extended product warranties for Argos, Sky and Samsung from rival private equity firm
fields.body:
CVC Capital partners has agreed to pay £750m to buy Domestic & General (D&G), which sells extended product warranties for Argos, Sky and Samsung.

The private equity firm will buy D&G from Advent International, a rival buyout outfit. Advent paid £524m to take the then-publicly listed company private at the height of the private equity boom in 2007.

Advent's profit will be less than the £226m difference between the two deals because D&G's management were given a stake in the business as part of the 2007 takeover. Advent will also have to pay Goldman Sachs and other advisers.

D&G sells service contracts on household appliances such as televisions, washing machines and other white goods and boilers. It does business in 11 countries, employs 2,500 staff and has 15 million customers.

D&G does not provide controversial point-of-sale extended warranties but it contacts customers on behalf of the manufacturer or retailer after the sale is made.

When Advent first put D&G up for sale it was said to be seeking up to £1bn though a spokesman said that was not the figure it had in mind.

Advent considered paying itself a special dividend and holding on to the company for another year or two but eventually agreed to sell to CVC.

UK private equity activity peaked in 2007 when acquisitions totalled $112bn (£72bn) and leading lights were accused by MPs of being asset strippers. Thomson Reuters figures show deals slumped to $8.5bn in 2009 but the sector staged a partial comeback to reach $28bn last year.

Private equity firms have traditionally taken public companies private to improve performance without pressure to produce short-term returns for shareholders. After a few years they would either refloat the company or sell it to a trade buyer.

They also used financial engineering to load the company up with tax-free debt. CVC did not say how much debt it would put into D&G as part of the deal. Advent used £434m of debt to buy D&G in 2007 – about 10 times the company's earnings.

In recent years, as with the D&G deal, buyout firms have increasingly sold businesses to each other. Advent said D&G's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation had increased to £83m in 2012, from £41m in 2008, and that the company had expanded in Europe.

CVC thinks it can improve D&G's profits further by providing management with more international contacts and knowledge to help expansion.

John Pearmund, D&G's chief executive, said: "We very much welcome the support, opportunities and resources which CVC will bring D&G to enable us to build further on our success to date in the UK and internationally."

Pearmund and his team are taking some cash out as part of the buyout but are said to be "rolling over" most of their stakes in D&G.

webTitle: UK inflation: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: Reactions to news that UK inflation eased to 2.8% in July
fields.body:
UK inflation eased to 2.8% in July, bolstering expectations among many economists that it is now headed back towards its 2% target after years of overshooting. Still, with wage rises at around just 1%, the slowdown will come as little relief to many households struggling with falling real incomes.

Here are reactions to the Office for National Statistics data:

Victoria Clarke at Investec

We do see CPI [consumer price index] inflation as having reached a peak in June 2013 and we expect it to slide further over the months ahead, helped in part by moderating food price inflation. However we note that input and output price inflation figures also published this morning pointed to some building price pressures at the factory gate with input price inflation reaching its fastest annual pace of increase since March 2012 at 5.0%. Hence, as this translates in part to factory gate prices this could cap any downside follow-through to CPI inflation over the months ahead.

One final point of note with today's figures is that the July inflation numbers provide the benchmark for increases in regulated rail fares for the year ahead. Regulated fares will be permitted to increase by July's 3.1% RPI inflation level plus 1%. At a time where wage growth remains subdued and still short of CPI inflation, let alone this pace of rail fare inflation, this would no doubt be unwelcome news for households affected and could dampen the recovery in consumer confidence and spending that is beginning to take hold.

Alan Clarke at Scotiabank

The recent rise in petrol prices was only partly captured by today's release – the bulk of that impact will come next month. It won't push inflation higher, it will just prevent the slowdown that we would otherwise have had.

Overall, no major surprises. It was another baby step back closer to the Bank of England's 2% target and it is going to be a long, slow journey downwards.

Nida Ali, economic adviser to the EY Item Club

Base effects had pushed the annual inflation rate up in June so it was always likely to unwind in July. But inflationary pressures seem to have eased, given that the price level stagnated on a month-on-month basis. Inflation has most likely peaked and will probably continue easing over the next few months. There is little sign of any inflationary pressure from the supply pipeline and, with global growth disappointing, commodity prices might soften further, therefore exerting a further downward pressure on prices.

Nevertheless, we see inflation remaining above the 2% target for the foreseeable future.

Scott Corfe, senior economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research

We expect inflation to fall back at the end of 2013 and into 2014, reaching close to the Bank of England's central target; we expect inflation on the CPI measure to average 2.2% next year. Cooling global commodity prices should provide respite to UK households and curb price growth, helping to abate ongoing cost of living pressures. However, with annual earnings growth languishing below the 2.0% mark, where we expect it to remain until 2015, households will still be seeing their spending power eroded for some time.

Andrew Sentance, senior economic adviser, PwC

The slight fall in inflation in July is welcome, but this is the 44th consecutive month of above-target inflation since the end of 2009. The CPI inflation rate remains uncomfortably close to 3% and a renewed surge in oil prices or a fall in the pound could push it back up again. UK inflation continues to run significantly above the rate of price increases in the US and euro area where it is below 2%.

David Brown at New View Economics

The drop in UK headline inflation from 2.9% to 2.8% will give the UK monetary authorities little to celebrate. The Bank's new-found forward guidance on interest rates based on unemployment may be one thing, but UK inflation is still stubbornly stuck too high for the BOE's comfort. The underlying upward tendency in UK inflation amid clearer signs that the UK economy is throwing off the mantle of recession suggests that the Bank is not going to hang around too long with record low rates at 0.5%. There is a very strong chance that the BOE will go along with basic instinct and go for higher rates well before the next UK general election which must be held before May 2015.

fields.standfirst: House prices in capital rose 8.1% in year to June, raising fears that Help to Buy scheme is fuelling new bubble
fields.body:
House prices in the capital rose at 8.1% in the year to June, the fastest pace since November 2010, according to the latest official figures, adding to fears that the government's policies may be stoking a property bubble in the capital.

The Office for National Statistics said on Tuesday that across the country, prices rose at an annual rate of 3.1% in June, up from 2.9% in May.

The ONS said house price growth remains stable across most of the UK, but the London market is pulling yet further ahead of the rest of the country, despite some evidence that the upturn is reaching other regions.

The West Midlands saw price growth of 3.1%, also the strongest since late 2010; but the cost of property is still falling in Scotland, Northern Ireland and Yorkshire and the Humber. Excluding London and the south-east, the ONS said the price rise in the year to June was a modest 1%.

George Osborne has faced criticism of the Help to Buy policy, which was announced in the budget, and has allowed purchasers of new-build homes to put down a deposit of just 5%, with the government offering an interest-free loan, worth up to 20% of the purchase price, to bridge the gap.

The Bank of England's Funding for Lending scheme has also boosted the housing market over the past 12 months, by helping to bring down the cost of mortgages.

The communities secretary, Eric Pickles, defended the coalition's housing policies on Tuesday, as he announced that more than 10,000 new homes have been reserved under the Help to Buy since its launch.

"This government's package of measures to boost the housing market is working, with house-building and housing supply on the up," he said. "By dealing with the big challenges, we are helping thousands of young people and families get on and move up the housing ladder, and Britain is building again.

The Department for Communities and Local Government said housing supply grew by 319,000 homes in the two years to October 2012.

The second, more controversial phase of the Help to Buy scheme, due to launch in January 2014, will make taxpayer-backed loans available to purchasers of properties worth up to £600,000.

The latest survey from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, published on Tuesday, suggested prices nationwide are increasing at their fastest pace since the market peak in 2006.

webTitle: UK inflation falls in July but consumers still under pressure

fields.standfirst: Rail fares rises will put further strain on workers contending with the biggest squeeze on living standards for decades
fields.body:
Inflation fell in July but remains well in excess of pay rises for the average British worker, leaving many households struggling with falling incomes.

The consumer price index (CPI) measure of the cost of living remained well above the Bank of England's government-set target, at 2.8%, while the broader retail price index (RPI), the measure of inflation used to set rail fares, was 3.1%. This means rail passengers now face fare rises of more than 4% in the new year.

Official statistics showed the RPI, which is also used to set many pay deals, eased to 3.1% in July from 3.3% in June. Both measures far outstripped average pay growth.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said CPI fell to 2.8% from 2.9% in June, as forecast by economists. The slowdown will bolster expectations that inflation is now heading lower after being above its 2% target for several years.

The Treasury welcomed the slowdown in inflation and sought to highlight moves such as freezing fuel duty as it contended with continued criticism over deteriorating household finances. A spokesperson said: "Inflation is at nearly half of its peak of 5.2%. The economy is on the mend, but the government understands that times are tough for families and that is why we have taken continued action to help with the cost of living."

But opposition Labour rebuffed government claims to be helping ease the burden of falling real wages.

Cathy Jamieson, Labour's shadow economic secretary to the Treasury said: "The government is making things worse not better for families. Alongside declining real wages, tax rises and cuts to tax credits are hitting those on middle and low incomes while millionaires have been given a huge tax cut."

Business groups welcomed signs that inflation is now coming down but said there were still risks price pressures could tick higher.

"There is now greater hope that increases in inflation above the 3% mark will be avoided, but the situation remains uncertain and renewed surges in energy prices could push inflation up again," said David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC).

Some economists predict inflation could be back at 2% by the end of the year. July's fall was "likely to presage the start of a sustained drop", said Martin Beck at Capital Economics.

"Other indicators point to further falls in inflation ahead. For example, producer prices figures also released today confirmed that price pressures at the very start of the inflation pipeline remain subdued. Looking forward, although there are growing signs of economic recovery, we think the degree of slack in the economy will help push down CPI inflation close to the monetary policy committee's 2% target by the end of the year."

The ONS said the slowdown in inflation came as higher petrol prices were outweighed by airfares rising less than a year ago and prices in the recreation and culture sector falling. There was also downward pressure on inflation from clothing, with prices dropping by more than a year ago.

Tuesday's official inflation numbers will be used to calculate January's rail fare rises across the network based on the formula of RPI plus one percentage point. That means regulated fares will likely rise by more than 4% at the start of 2014, adding more than £200 to the annual price of commuters' tickets in the south-east of England.

That will put further strain on workers contending with the biggest squeeze on living standards for decades as pay rises fail to keep pace with rises in the cost of living. Average pay growth stands at 1%, according to the ONS.

"This slightly eases the squeeze on consumers' purchasing power, although it currently remains appreciable given that inflation is still running nearly three times above underlying annual average earnings growth," said Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight.

"Looking ahead, consumer price inflation may yet touch 3.0% in the near term given difficult near-term base effects and recently firmer oil prices … but it should start heading gradually down towards the end of the year."

This latest easing in inflation will bring reassurance to the Bank of England and new governor Mark Carney, who last week vowed to keep interest rates at their record low.

The Bank's latest forecasts are for inflation to remain above its 2% government-set target until the second half of 2015. But Carney has signalled borrowing costs will remain unchanged until well after the 2015 general election, stressing that only a big fall in unemployment would bring an end to the cheap money of the past four years. The governor said he would wait until the jobless rate lowered to 7% before considering whether to push up rates. That milestone is probably a long way off and official labour market data published on Wednesday are expected to put unemployment at 7.8%.

webTitle: Let-up in food price rises expected to have eased inflation in July

fields.standfirst: Numbers signal little relief for rail passengers facing fare increases of more than 4% at start of 2014
fields.body:
A let-up in food price rises is expected to have brought down inflation in July, but that will come as scant reassurance to rail passengers facing hefty fare hikes and households struggling with falling incomes.

Tuesday'sofficial inflation numbers will be used to calculate January's rail fare rises across the network. With retail price inflation expected to top 3%, based on the formula of RPI plus one percentage point, that means regulated fares may rise by more than 4% at the start of 2014, adding more than £200 to the annual price of commuters' tickets in the south-east.

That will put further strain on workers contending with the biggest squeeze on living standards for decades as pay rises fail to keep pace with rises in the cost of living. But economists do expect Tuesday's numbers to indicate the worst is over on inflation.

The City expects headline consumer price inflation (CPI) to have eased slightly in July when the Office for National Statistics publishes the latest numbers at 9.30am. Thanks to an expected slowdown in food price inflation and despite likely upward pressure from higher petrol prices, consumer price inflation is seen dipping to 2.8% in July from 2.9% in June, according to a Reuters poll of economists.

The retail price measure of inflation, which also includes housing costs and is used to help set many pay deals as well as rail fares, is seen easing to 3.1% from 3.3% in June.

Thinktank Capital Economics is forecasting CPI inflation of 2.7% and says these latest numbers should mark the start of a downward trend in price pressures, with a good chance that inflation will fall to about 2% by the end of the year.

"Admittedly, the contribution of petrol prices to inflation will increase slightly in July. Prices at the pump rose by about 0.5% last month, but fell by 1% in July 2012. Nonetheless, food price inflation could fall a bit further," they wrote in a preview.

Any let-up in CPI will reassure Bank of England policymakers, who have vowed to keep interest rates low rather than tighten policy in a bid to bring down inflation.

The Bank's latest forecasts published under the new governor, Mark Carney, last week are for inflation to remain above its 2% government-set target until the second half of 2015. But the central bank has been at pains to reassure markets, businesses and households that interest rates will stay at their record low.

Carney signalled borrowing costs would remain unchanged until well after the 2015 general election, stressing that only a big fall in unemployment would bring an end to the cheap money of the past four years.

In a bid to cement Britain's recovery from recession, the governor said he would wait until the jobless rate lowered to 7% before considering whether to push up rates. That milestone is probably a long way off and official labour market data published on Wednesday is expected to put unemployment at 7.8%.

Economists generally agree that although inflation is still above its target and has been dragging on consumer spending by squeezing household budgets, the worst is now over and price pressures are easing.

"We suspect that CPI inflation reached a peak at 2.9% in June and is set to decline from here, potentially falling below the Bank's 2% target in the early part of 2014," said Victoria Clarke, economist at Investec. She forecasts July CPI of 2.6% thanks to a sharp drop in clothes prices from June.

The ONS also releases factory gate price data on Tuesday and economists generally expect the numbers to show costs for producers picked up at a faster pace in July but they did not pass much of that on. Input price inflation is seen accelerating to 5.5% from 4.2% in June. Output prices, also known as factory gate prices, are seen up by an annual 2.1% after 2% inflation in June.

Capital Economics said: "While July's producer prices data are likely to show a pick-up in factory gate prices, the bigger picture is one of subdued pipeline inflationary pressures."
